ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to work on collaborative design with a person living with dementia as I conducted research on dementia stigma reduction interventions.

For students reading this on CourseTable - this was my senior thesis research lab, which was Julia Leonard's Developmental Psychology Lab. Each lab is obviously different, but I think joining one is such an amazing opportunity and so would recommend to anyone. For Julia's lab, scale that up 1000x.

This was my third semester in Julia's lab, and it's hands down been the best academic experience I've had at Yale. The culture and environment in the lab is fantastic, Julia was incredibly generous with her time and energy and I don't think there's anything I would change about how this semester went, or even my last 3 semester in this lab.
I learned how to do coding, understand data and collaborate effectively with others. I often had to meet deadlines.

Im incredibly grateful to have taken this course and having had the privilege to work in Professor Richesons lab under Hyeonjin Baks guidance. Thanks for their incredible mentorship, i now know how to do literature review, code and design studies and analyze & interpret data, as well as propose my own research studies.
I gained the necessary skills to conduct psychology research and analyze the data I got from my experiments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Having the space to pursue this work was crucial to furthering my career goals.

As a 'directed research' course, this semester involved my running the final studies for my thesis and then writing it all up. The help I got from everyone in the lab was incredible and my thesis genuinely wouldn't have happened without at least 6 of the current lab members. Julia especially was a fantastic advisor and I'm sad to be graduating and unable to continue in this team.
There is literally no weakness to this course. I am very grateful to having had the chance to work in the Social Perception and Communication Laboratory as a Research Assistant.
There was a lot of flexibility which was great for my busy schedule. From my experience, I have a lot of say in what I wanted to explore and how I wanted to go about conducting my studies.
very flexible schedule which was nice as a fifth credit

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend an independent study to anyone interested in working with a Yale faculty member outside of the classroom, developing skills not traditionally taught in classes that are offered.

Yes! It was my thesis class, so if you're a Psych/CogSci major and you want to get the BS, you might have to join a lab and do 'directed research'. But if you're still deciding whether to do BA or BS, DO THE BS!! So much more interesting and rewarding than writing without data, and if there's the opportunity to run your own study in some way, or adapt other research, take it and run. It's such a unique chance to behave like a grad student for a semester, and being part of a lab like this teaches you tons.
Id definitely recommend it to another student if the labs work fits into their research interests!
If you want the opportunity to take charge in psychology research, this is the class to do it in.
